Tuning double metal cyanide catalysts with complexing agents for the selective production of cyclic carbonates over polycarbonates Jose Tharun Manju Mamparambath Dharman Yeseul Hwang Roshith Roshan Moon Seok Park Dae-Won Park ⁎ Division of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, Pusan National University, Busan 609-735, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 51 510 2399; fax: +82 51 512 8563. Graphical abstract Highlights ► Double metal cyanide (DMC) complexes based on (Zn3[Co(CN)6]2) were successfully synthesized. ► Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB), tert-butanol and/or PEG–PPG–PEG were used as complexing agents. ► The DMC catalysts were very efficient for the selective production of styrene carbonate over polycarbonate. ► No additional solvent was used for the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide and styrene oxide. A double metal cyanide (DMC) complex based on (Zn3[Co(CN)6]2), an effective catalyst for the ring opening polymerization of epoxides and the copolymerization of carbon dioxide with epoxides, was successfully utilized for the solvent-free cycloaddition of CO2 to styrene oxide (SO) by the introduction of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as a complexing agent (CA). Several DMC catalysts were prepared by introducing co-complexing agents (co-CAs) along with the CA. From the XRD data, it was clear that all the catalysts were amorphous with no peak corresponding to the precursor ZnCl2. XPS analysis was performed to explain the successful introduction of the CA to the DMC catalyst, in which the binding energy of the zinc atom shifted from precursor ZnCl2 to DMC. Elemental analysis and FT-IR also confirmed the incorporation of the CA with Zn3[Co(CN)6]2. The DMC complex was proven to be an effective catalyst for the solvent-free synthesis of styrene carbonate by the cycloaddition of styrene oxide and CO2. This paper reports the tunability of the metal cyanide catalysts with CA for the selective preparation of cyclic carbonates over polycarbonates. 1H NMR and FT-IR confirmed product formation. The effects of reaction parameters like catalyst amount, temperature, CO2 pressure, and reaction time were also investigated. Keywords Double metal cyanide Carbon dioxide Styrene oxide Styrene carbonate 1 Introduction One approach to mitigate carbon dioxide emission to atmosphere would be the development of commercially viable synthetic routes for basic chemicals that employ CO2 as the starting material [1–5]. CO2 is an ideal synthetic feedstock since it is abundant, inexpensive, nontoxic, and nonflammable. Due to their high reactivity, epoxides can be effectively reacted with CO2 for the production of either polycarbonates or cyclic carbonates. The past three decades have witnessed great progress in the fixation of CO2 into polycarbonates, building on the innovative work of Inoue et al. [6]. Cyclic carbonates have gained considerable attention due to their broad spectrum of applications; for example, as aprotic polar solvents, electrolytes in secondary batteries, precursors for polycarbonates and other polymeric materials, and intermediates in the production of pharmaceuticals and fine chemicals [7–9]. The production of cyclic carbonates from epoxides and CO2 is attractive from the viewpoint of green chemistry and the chemical fixation of CO2 [10]. The synthesis of cyclic carbonates from the reaction of CO2 with epoxides has been performed using Lewis acids, transition-metal complexes, and organometallic compounds as catalysts under high pressure [8–11]. There are several reports for the synthesis of five-membered cyclic carbonates under mild conditions in the presence of metal halides or quaternary ammonium salts [12,13]. Double metal cyanide (DMC) complexes are well-known catalysts effective for the ring-opening polymerization and copolymerization of epoxides [14–17]. DMC is comprised of a metal ion (M1 is an oxophilic metal) which forms a strong bond to oxygen and a metal (M2 is a transition metal) cyanide salt, e.g., [M1] n [M2(CN)6] m . Among the DMC complexes, the catalyst based on Zn3[Co(CN)6]2 is generally considered the best. Despite the use of the same precursors, the catalytic activities of DMC complexes were found to be profoundly dependent on the synthesis methods adopted. Pure DMC catalysts prepared in the absence of complexing agents (CAs) were generally less active. Usually, organic and polymeric CAs are incorporated into the catalyst matrix to impart activity. In this sense, the choice of CAs is one of the key parameters in designing the active DMC catalysts. Nevertheless, these complex catalysts are poorly defined with respect to a detailed understanding of their structures and reaction pathways [14,15]. In our previous work, copolymers of various epoxides with CO2 were synthesized successfully, employing several different DMC catalysts [16,17]. Recently, our group also studied the cooperative effect between the DMC complex and quaternary ammonium salts, leading to the production of cyclic carbonates instead of polycarbonates under solvent-free conditions [18]. The role of the quaternary ammonium salt along with the DMC complex is to open the epoxide ring, which then reacts with carbon dioxide and cyclizes to give the cyclic carbonate in exceptionally high yields. Herein, we made an attempt to overcome the disadvantages of using two different catalysts by engaging cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as a CA during the preparation of DMC complexes. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Zinc chloride (≥98%), potassium hexacyanocobaltate(III) (K3Co(CN)6), tert-butanol (99+%), poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(propylene glycol)-block-poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG–PPG–PEG; M n =1100), and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) (≥98%) were purchased from Aldrich and used without further purification. Styrene oxide (SO), and other epoxides were also obtained from Aldrich and used as received. Carbon dioxide of 99.999% purity was used without further purification. CH2Cl2 was obtained from SK Chemicals, Korea, and used as received. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis All the DMC catalysts based on Zn–Co were synthesized according to a previously reported procedure [19]. The following methodology was adopted to synthesize DMC-1. Solution 1 was prepared by dissolving 0.01mol of potassium hexacyanocobaltate(III) in 40mL distilled water. Solution 2 was prepared by dissolving 0.1mol of ZnCl2 in 100mL distilled water. Solution 3 was prepared by dissolving 0.01mol of CTAB in 40mL distilled water. Solution 2 was added slowly to solution 1 over 1h at 50°C with vigorous stirring, which resulted in the precipitation of a white solid. Solution 3 was then added to the above reaction mixture over a 10min interval with constant stirring for a further 1h. The resulting solid was filtered, washed thoroughly with distilled water, and dried at 60°C for several hours under vacuum. A method similar to DMC-1 synthesis was used for the synthesis of DMC-2 and DMC-3, except that a tri-block copolymer PEG–PPG–PEG (15mL in 2mL distilled water) (DMC-2) and tert-butanol (20mL) (DMC-3) were used as co-complexing agents (co-CAs) along with the CA (CTAB). DMC-4 was prepared with CTAB and all the above co-CAs. 2.3 Characterization The catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Fourier transform infra-red spectroscopy (FT-IR), elemental analysis (EA), and inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). FT-IR and 1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR, 500MHz) were used to confirm the product obtained. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Philips PANalytical X’pert PRO Model power diffractometer operating at 40kV and 30mA using Ni filtered Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.5404Å). The diffractograms were recorded in the 2θ range 10–80°. XPS analyses were performed using an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (VG, ESCALAB 250) with monochromatic Al Kα radiation (hν =1486.6eV). The binding energies (BE) were calculated using the C 1s band as the reference (284.6eV). The FT-IR spectra were obtained on an AVATAR 370 Thermo Nicolet spectrophotometer with a resolution of 4cm−1. Elemental analyses of the catalysts were carried out using a Vario EL III analyzer. The metal contents of the catalysts were obtained from ICP-OES analysis using ULTIMA2 CHR (1.5kW, 40.68MHz, 130–800mm) with mono chromato HDD and a poly chromato PMT detector. 1H NMR spectra of the cyclic carbonate were obtained on a Varian 500MHz using CDCl3 as solvent. 2.4 Cycloaddition of styrene oxide with CO2 The synthesis of the cyclic carbonate from styrene oxide (SO) and CO2 (Scheme 1 ) using the DMC-1 catalyst was performed in a 50mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. For each typical batch operation, DMC catalyst (20mg) and SO (18.6mmol) were charged into the reactor without solvent, and then purged several times with CO2. The reactor was then pressurized with CO2 to a preset pressure, 0.34–1.17MPa, at room temperature. The reactor was heated to a desired temperature, and then the reaction was started by stirring the reaction mixture at 600rpm. The reactor pressure was increased by about 0.03–0.10MPa depending on the reaction temperature, due to the vapor pressure of the reactants. After the completion of reaction time, cycloaddition was stopped by cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature and venting the remaining CO2. The product was dissolved in dichloromethane and filtered to remove the catalyst. Product analysis was carried out by FT-IR, 1H NMR, and gas chromatography/mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Micromass, UK) analysis. The conversion of SO was obtained from gas chromatography (GC, HP 6890, Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA, USA) data. 3 Results and discussion Zn3[Co(CN)6] based double metal cyanide complexes are currently used as catalysts for both the ring-opening polymerization of epoxides and the copolymerization of epoxides and CO2. These complexes are generally prepared by a precipitation reaction between K3[M(CN)6] (where M=Cr, Co, Fe, etc.) and metal salts (e.g., ZnCl2, ZnSO4, CoCl2, etc.) with the CAs [20]. ZnCl2 is generally regarded as the most effective precursor for preparing the DMC catalysts, and excess ZnCl2 was needed for superior activity of the resultant catalyst. This means that the active site of the DMC catalyst has a strong correlation with excess ZnCl2. The crystallinity of the catalyst might influence the catalytic activity to some extent. Indeed, the highly crystalline DMC complexes prepared in the absence of any CAs showed no activity. The role of the CAs in the synthesis of the DMC complexes was confirmed by their enhanced catalytic activity toward the ring opening polymerization as well as the copolymerization of epoxides with CO2 [21–23]. The usually employed CAs are low molecular weight functional polymers (PEG–PPG–PEG, PTMEG, PPG, etc.) and organic compounds (tert-butanol). The presence of quaternary ammonium salts along with DMC complexes resulted in the selective production of cyclic carbonates over polycarbonates [18]. Herein, we report the synthesis and catalytic activity of single-component catalysts which are built on the mechanistic understanding of the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides and combine the key features of DMC complexes and quaternary ammonium salts within a single entity. For the preparation of DMC complexes, cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) is introduced as a CA, which would eventually serve the role of a quaternary ammonium salt for the selective production of cyclic carbonates over polycarbonates. 3.1 Characterization of DMC catalysts The surface formulation of the catalysts was examined by XPS and XRD, and the electronic properties were determined by FT-IR. Table 1 summarizes the XPS results. The binding energy of the zinc atom (the 2p3 XPS line at 1023.7eV) in ZnCl2 shifted to lower values, due to the formation of the zinc hexacyanocobaltate-based catalyst. As the electron-withdrawing power of the ligands bound to Zn atom decreases due to the substitution of Cl ligands by CN ligands the coordination of complexing agents to coordinatively unsaturated Zn metal centers leads the chemical shift to lower values [24]. From the XRD analysis shown in Fig. 1 , it is clear that all the catalysts were amorphous with no peaks corresponding to precursor ZnCl2. The CAs used in the synthesis of the DMC complexes were CTAB, tert-butanol, and PEG–PPG–PEG. DMC-1 catalyst, prepared using CTAB as CA, showed the lowest crystallinity. DMC-2 (CTAB and PEG–PPG–PEG), DMC-3 (CTAB and tert-butanol), and DMC-4 (CTAB, PEG–PPG–PEG, and tert-butanol), respectively, showed lower crystallinity compared to ZnCl2. All the DMC catalysts showed almost similar d-spacing values, indicating that the structures were not substantially altered upon the addition of the CAs [15]. Fig. 2 shows FT-IR spectra for the various DMC complexes. The ν(CN) of K3[Co(CN)6] (about 2133cm−1) shifted to higher wave numbers such as 2193cm−1 in DMC-1 and DMC-2, and 2187cm−1 in DMC-3 and DMC-4. The ν(CN) of free CN− is 2080cm−1. The ν(CN) shift to higher frequencies suggests that CN− acts as a σ-donor by donating electrons to the Co3+ and as a π-electron donor by chelating to Zn2+, which is responsible for raising the ν(CN) value [20]. In the far-IR region, M–N stretching vibrations appear in 470–320cm−1. Thus, a close examination of the lower frequency infrared region helps us to establish the metal–nitrogen coordination in the complexes [25]. The presence of a weak band at around 468cm−1 establishes Zn–N coordination in the complexes. The total composition of the DMC complexes obtained from elemental analysis and ICP-OES results are detailed in Table 2 . In all the DMC catalysts Zn/Co weight% ratio remains nearly same, with Zn content in excess, indicative of the possibility of surfeit ZnCl2 complexed onto DMC thereby increasing the number of active sites [26]. 3.2 Product selectivity: cyclic carbonate over polycarbonate Fig. 3 shows the FT-IR spectra of the samples after 6h of the reaction of SO with CO2 at 100 and 140°C. The intense absorbance at about 1800cm−1 corresponds to the ν(CO2) vibration of the cyclic carbonate; differentiating its formation from the polycarbonate copolymer stretch which usually appears around 1750cm−1 [16]. Generally, the formation of polycarbonates predominates at lower reaction temperatures [27]. Even at lower temperatures, a strong absorption around 1800cm−1 with a high energy shoulder indicates the selective formation of cyclic carbonates over polycarbonates. The absence of polycarbonate formation (the absence of peak at 1750cm−1) even at lower reaction temperature excluded the depolymerization mechanism [18]. The splitting of peak around the region of 1790–1820cm−1 indicates stereo selectivity of the cyclic products formed. The higher energy shoulder of the peak at 1812cm−1 is due to the cis-styrene carbonate whereas the lower energy shoulder at 1796cm−1 is by the formation of trans-styrene carbonate. The presence of the ionized CTAB species in the DMC catalysts may hinder the growth of the polymer chain, thereby promoting a ring closure pathway toward the selective production of cyclic carbonate [4]. 1H NMR analysis in CDCl3 shown in Fig. 4 also confirms the product formed is cyclic carbonate (a =5.6ppm, b =4.6ppm, b′= 4.4ppm). Here, the introduction of CTAB as a CA favors the cycloaddition reaction over the copolymerization of CO2 with epoxides. 3.3 Influence of different DMC complexes and epoxides on cyclic carbonate synthesis To investigate the catalytic activity of DMC complexes, a batch reaction was performed with styrene oxide (SO) and CO2 as represented in Scheme 1. All cycloaddition reactions were performed under the same conditions (140°C, 1.17MPa, 6h) using the same amounts of catalysts and SO. As shown in Table 3 , the obtained SO conversions ranged from 87% to 93% with >94% styrene carbonate (SC) selectivity. The high selectivity indicated negligible formation of byproducts in the cycloaddition reaction. Among the four different DMC complexes, DMC-1 was found to be the most active and have the highest turnover number (TON) of 3486. Zn3[Co(CN)6] catalyst prepared from potassium hexacyanocobaltate and ZnCl2 with tert-butanol and PEG–PPG–PEG showed TON of 978 when nBu4NCl was used as co-catalyst for the synthesis of SC at 140°C for 6h [18]. Compared to our previously reported results for the cyclic carbonate synthesis with ionic liquids supported on silica materials [28–31], showing TOF of 4–40h−1, DMC-1 in Table 3 showed much higher TOF of 581h−1. Therefore, further studies used DMC-1 as a catalyst for the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2. A series of epoxide substrates were examined for the synthesis of the corresponding cyclic carbonates using DMC-1 as shown in Table 4 (1.17MPa, 120–140°C, 4–12h). Aliphatic epoxides and CO2 produced the corresponding cyclic carbonates with high TON over 3000. The disubstituted epoxide, cyclohexene oxide, exhibited lower activity in the production of the corresponding cyclic carbonate, probably due to the effect of the high steric hindrance offered by the cyclohexene ring [32]. All cyclic carbonates were obtained with very high selectivities (over 96%) and were identified by GC/MS. 3.4 Influence of reaction parameters Since DMC-1 showed good catalytic activity, it was employed to examine the effects of reaction parameters (catalyst amount, time, temperature, and CO2 pressure) on the cycloaddition reaction of SO with CO2. First, the relationship between SO conversion and catalyst amount was investigated. Fig. 5 demonstrates that conversion increased with an increase in catalyst amount up to 20mg. Further increase in catalyst amount did not bring up any significant increment in the conversion, probably because of the hindrance in mass transfer occurred between active site and reagent caused by the low dispersity of excess catalyst in the reaction mixture [33]. Fig. 6 shows the relationship between SO conversion and reaction time. The conversion increased with lengthening reaction duration. Prolonging reaction time beyond 6h gave a little increase in SC yield indicating that 6h is optimal. Fig. 7 shows the dependence of SO conversion on temperature. As is shown, the SO conversion increased from 14% to 63% with increasing reaction temperature from 100°C to 120°C, and showed the maximum conversion of 93% with 99% SC selectivity at 140°C. This temperature and conversion relationship was attributed to higher reactivity at elevated temperatures. Further increase in temperature resulted in a decrease in SC yield apparently due to the concomitant decrease of CO2 solubility in the reaction system at elevated temperature. Therefore, 140°C is considered a suitable reaction temperature. The effect of CO2 pressure was also investigated (Fig. 8 ). At a low CO2 pressure of 0.34MPa, the conversion was 65%. At higher CO2 pressures of 0.82 and 0.97MPa, SO conversion increased to 83% and 87%, respectively. At 1.17MPa, the reaction yielded the highest conversion, 93%. During such catalytic reactions, higher CO2 pressure can effectively increase the solubility of CO2 in SO, enabling the reaction equilibrium to shift toward carbonate formation. However, it was reported that too high a CO2 pressure could decrease the conversion due to the effect of dilution by excessive quantities of CO2 [34–36]. 3.5 Proposed mechanism of cycloaddition reaction The main role of the complexing agent is to help form the amorphous DMC catalyst in the precipitation process, and thereby increase the catalytic activity. However, part of the complexing agent remains in the DMC catalyst. It may also coordinate with the zinc center and might be the dominant active site. For these reactions, a zinc active site in the DMC complexes serves as a Lewis acid for the activation of epoxides and Br− functions as a nucleophile for the ring-opening of the epoxide. The formation of the cyclic carbonate (Fig. 9 ) occurs through a back-biting mechanism; the factors enhancing the cyclization path include higher temperatures and the presence of a strong anionic leaving group (Br−) that helps dissociate the growing polymer chain from the metal center [37]. The mechanism involves attack of the anion at the least hindered carbon of the epoxide, carbon dioxide insertion, intermolecular cyclization, and reformation of the anion. 4 Conclusions DMC catalysts were successfully synthesized by the introduction of CTAB as a CA. Characterizations by XRD, XPS, FT-IR, EA, and ICP-OES, were performed to confirm the structural formation of catalyst. The DMC complex was proven to be an effective catalyst for the solvent-free synthesis of styrene carbonate by the cycloaddition of styrene oxide and CO2. FT-IR and 1H NMR confirmed product formation. Good conversion (93%) and yield (92%) were obtained under moderate reaction conditions. The effects of reaction parameters such catalyst amount, temperature, CO2 pressure, and reaction time were also investigated. By tuning the complexing agent (CTAB), cyclic carbonates can be selectively prepared over polycarbonates. Here DMC–CTAB acts as a single-component catalyst for the selective preparation of cyclic carbonates.
